title: AMS Maturity Levels: From Firefighting to Decision Platform
hook: Most SAP AMS teams believe they are mature because systems are running. Real maturity starts when the system improves itself.
idea: AMS maturity is not about tools or headcount. It’s about how reliably the organization turns incidents and changes into stability, learning, and lower cost.
core_principle: Each level is defined by dominant behavior and control loops — not by intentions.

maturity_levels.name: Firefighting AMS
dominant_behavior: Heroes and experts keep the system alive

maturity_levels.name: Controlled Operations AMS
dominant_behavior: Incidents and changes are managed via process
typical_signs: Lower chaos, but repeats still exist
Prevention is discussed but rarely funded

maturity_levels.name: Prevention-Driven AMS
dominant_behavior: Demand drivers are measured and reduced
typical_signs: Problems have owners and ROI logic

maturity_levels.name: Automation & Agentic AMS
dominant_behavior: Agents assist triage, diagnosis, and decisions

maturity_levels.name: Decision Platform AMS
dominant_behavior: AMS frames business and IT decisions
Options are compared with impact, cost, and risk
System boundaries and lock-in are managed intentionally
typical_signs: AMS involved before changes are requested

transition_rules: You cannot skip levels — behavior must change first.
Each level requires killing specific anti-patterns.
Progress is measured by trends, not milestones.
diagnostic_questions: Do repeat incidents automatically trigger elimination work?
Is prevention capacity protected under pressure?
Can knowledge be retrieved and reused under stress?
Are decisions documented with options and outcomes?
Does AMS reduce future dependency, or reinforce it?

copilot_moves: Assess maturity signals from incident, change, and backlog data.
Highlight behaviors anchoring the team at current level.
Suggest next-level practices with highest leverage.

design_question: Which behavior keeps your AMS stuck at the current level — and what would it take to block it?
